messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> Of course the bath problem is incurable in any spelling reform project:
> - Either you have separate letters for the "trap" sound and the "palm"
> sound in which case for the word "bath" some speakers will use one and
> some the other; this is the QS approach.
> - Or you have just one letter to represent both the "trap" and "bath"
> sound in which case "moss" and "mass" will be spelled the same.

Or you allocate separate letters for BATH and CLOTH. But nobody's
been that clever yet.

(Of course, there's a question where to stop. The English of Wales,
for example, has an extra lexical set JUICE [iw] distinct from
GOOSE [u], and in Scotland "fer(n)", "fur", and "fir" are in
separate lexical sets, as the local dialect never had that merger.)

> > More practically in my case, I need to know what letter to use in words
> > like "Pot" so that readers from all over the world can read the news
> > relatively easy. Using my Boston accent as a guide seems unwise.

A Boston accent actually works well, because the only mergers not
involving R (that is, ones like PALM = START) are the BATH and CLOTH
ones; LOT, THOUGHT, and PALM are all differentiated.

--
John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
